results.title: Norman's new garden
results.creator_credit: Gibson Film Productions and Dave Gibson
results.brief_description: This humorous film is designed to show the need for and the importance of trees and plants in one’s own environment. Two men, friends from boyhood, grow up and each buy a house. However, one sits back and plants nothing, while the other diligently and patiently creates a garden paradise. Ten years later, the lazier of the two sees the folly of his idleness.
results.description: This humorous film is designed to show the need for and the importance of trees and plants in one’s own environment. Two men, friends from boyhood, grow up and each buy a house. results.title: Normal and abnormal neurologic function in infancy
results.creator_credit: Dept of Pediatrics, Ohio State University
results.brief_description: This film is designed to illustrate how infant motor function can provide a valuable diagnostic tool for early detection of intellectual impairment. Employing extensive clinical footage, the filmmakers have sought to depict characteristic defects of co-ordination where these exist either independently of, or as a result of, childhood brain injury.

results.title: Norma
results.creator_credit: Australian Opera, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Sandro Sequi and William Fitzwater
results.brief_description: Norma, the opera by Bellini, libretto by Felice Romani, based on a drama by Alexandre Soumet and directed by Sandro Sequi, is set in Gaul during the Roman occupation about 50 BC. Norma, the Druid High priestess, sung by Dame Joan Sutherland, breaks her vows of chastity with the Roman Pollione, sung by Ron Stevens. In a tangled tale of love and tragedy, the two lovers pay the ultimate sacrifice for their love and die together. Features singers Clifford Grant (Oroveso), Trevor Brown (Flavio), Margreta Elkins (Adalgisa), Etela Piha (Clotilde), and The Australian Opera Chorus. Also features The Elizabethan Sydney Orchestra conducted by Richard Bonynge. Recorded at the Sydney Opera House on 1 August 1978 and produced for television in association with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Restored and released in 1991 by The Australian Opera. Sung in Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: Norm and Ahmed (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Tristram Miall, Film Australia and Karl McPhee
results.brief_description: Twenty years after its creation, Norm and Ahmed, remains a classic in Australian literature. This video of the play features the well-known actor Max Cullen as Norm and Alex Pinder as Ahmed. The action centres on a midnight meeting between Norm, an average Australian, who embodies the ocker image and Ahmed, an urbane Pakistan student. The chance encounter starts off in a friendly enough manner, but underneath Norm’s veneer of mateyness lies a distrust of the unfamiliar and a defensiveness which turns nasty when Norm feels threatened. The themes of racism and prejudices in the play are still pertinent today.

results.title: Norfolk Island: From Hell to Paradise
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
Norfolk Island is an eight by six kilometre paradise set in the blue waters of the South West Pacific Ocean about 1,500 kilometres east of the Australian mainland. The island was secured by the British in 1788 just a few weeks after settlement at Sydney Cove. It was abandoned after a few years, until 1824 when it became one of the most terrible and feared penal settlements. The graveyards and chronicles testify to the brutality and terror of those awful years. The island was abandoned but eventually re-settled by descendants of the Bounty mutineers who moved there from the more isolated Pitcairn Island in 1856.

results.title: Norfolk Island
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Don Murray
results.brief_description: The tourist attractions of Norfolk Island. Today tourists can fly to Norfolk Island for the scenery and the simplicity of an island holiday amongst volcanic ridges and sub-tropical vegetation where they can enjoy fishing, golfing, surfing and other sports. There are also reminders to be seen of the island’s historic past: ruins of convict buildings and stables, Bloody Bridge, and St. Barnabas Chapel built by the Melanesian Mission.

results.title: Nonverbal communication (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Harper & Row, Stanley Milgram and Harry From
results.brief_description: Examines scientific findings on communication through gesture, body posture, intonation, eye contact, and facial expression. Includes interviews with experts on interpersonal distance, the equilibrium theory of eye contact, sex differences in the perception of nonverbal behaviour, gestures and expression in photos, and biological programing.

results.title: Nonsense = Nesmysl
results.creator_credit: Kratky Film, Milos Macourek, Vykasnik Born and Hudba Fiser
results.brief_description: The everchanging daydreams of a small boy are viewed with suspicion by his friends, his parents, and his doctor. However, when his parents realise that his dreams have commercial value, the boy is exploited until his dreams, like the flowers that inspire him, wither and die. Animated with music and sound effects. No spoken language. Animators: Janoslav Doubrava, Josef Hekrala, Vera Macesova

results.title: Nonoonse Anishinabe Ishichekewin Ka Kanawentank
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Jerry Krepakevich, Michael Scott, Sara Berger and Elise Swerhone
results.brief_description: Western pioneers knew that sugar could be made from the sap of the Manitoba maple. But the trees were small, the sap was thin, and the tastier product of Quebec and Ontario was cheap and easy to get. The settler soon turned away from the arduous annual harvest and the Manitoba maple became just another tree. But not for Nonoonse. Forty years ago her grandmother brought her to Sugar Island. Since then she has returned every spring to gather the sweet sap. Filmed on Lake Manitoba, near the Ebb’n’Flow Reserve, Nonoonse is both a clear description of sugar-making and a quiet statement on the importance of the tradition to the Saultaux Indians of the region. (Bilingual: English and Saulteaux.)
